Noicee

f(x) = x² - 1/x - 1
Let's say, x = 1

f(1) = 1² (1) - 1/1 - 1 = 0/0, which is Mathematically undefined

So, forget 1, let's try 1.5
f(1.5) = 1.5² (2.25) - 1/1.5 - 1 = 1.25/0.5 = 2.5

So that was properly defined. Let's try 1.25
f(1.25) = 1.25² (1.56) - 1/1.25 - 1 = 0.56/0.25 = 2.24

Ok, now we're inching closer to pure 1. Let's try 1.1
f(1.1) = 1.1² (1.21) - 1/1.1 - 1 = 0.21/0.1 = 2.1

Do you notice a pattern? The closer we get 1, the closer our answer becomes 2, but when we get to pure 1, our answer is undefined. This would be represented as this equation:
lim(x - 1) x² - 1/x - 1 = 2
The Limit when going from x (anything) to 1, when the question is x² - 1/x - 1 is 2. You see this because the closer we get to pure 1, the closer our answer gets to 2, but the when we actually use pure 1 as x, our answer is undefined. That's a limit.

Summary of the first part as it was a bit confusing:
F(1) meaning substitute 1 into the equation would give u 0. That is not possible on this graph because it is literally a fancy way of saying y=1. Y=1 is a straight line as he drew. But if we said x=1 then y=0.
so we leave that part empty because u can’t “define it” ie the solution doesn’t work here.
“BUT I WANNA KNOW THE SOLUTION OF y=f(x) WHERE x=1 !”
Ok nerd but I just said can’t do that. But what we can do is beat the system and find the solution jusssssst next to that point where u got 1 on the x axis. So in this instance, we get 1 on both sides of that point. So we get an IDEA of its solution. But again, we cant say that THAT EXACT POINT is 1 cuz
(1-1)/(1-1) doesn’t work out.

Let f (x) be defined and single-valued for all values of x near x = x0 with
the possible exception of x = x0 itself (i.e., in a deleted δ neighborhood of
x0). We say that the number l is the limit of f (x) as x approaches x0 and
we write
lim
x→x0
f (x) → l, (5)
if for any positive number (however small) we can find some positive
number δ (usually depending on ) such that
|f (x) − l| < , whenever, 0 < |x − x0| < δ. (6)
In such case we also say that f (x) approaches l as x approaches x0 and
write f (x) → l as x → x0. Therefore, we see that no restriction is made as
to how x should approach x0. Therefore, considering x and x0 as points on
the real axis where x0 is fixed and x is moving, then x can approach x0
from the right or from the left. We indicate these respective approaches by
writing

personal notes for me...
-----------------------------------
g(x) = y or y axis value

in video,
this is
g(x) or y = { x^2 , x =\= 2; 1 , x = 2}
this is a way of defining a function, here this one specifically means is

if g of x or y is equal to x^2 then dont take 2 as the value of x, you can take any thing else but two.

if g of x or y is equal to 1 at any point on function then value of x will be equal to 2

thats just how function is defined

Calculus students don’t fret if you don’t grasp limits. They are only proofs that calculus is valid.  Unless you are a mathematics major, you will only encounter limits superficially in other scientific courses.  What you are being taught now was not developed until the 1880s.  This means that all the progress with calculus from the time of Newton and Leibniz in the 1680s was achieved without any satisfactory validating proofs as to why calculus worked.  Derivatives can be achieved according to a set of rules; integrals have fewer useful rules; limits have no rules.  Each limit problem requires a different approach, and examples provided are usually too simple to help.  When you reach the point of not knowing how to
proceed, you are in a pool of millions. Don't get discouraged, the rest of calculus is much easier to understand.

how to prove 0/0=2
0/0=(100-100)/(100-100)
=({10x10} - {10x10})/({10x10} - {10x10})
=({10-10}{10+10})/(10{10-10})
=20/10[because (10-10) in numerator is also in the denominator] 
=2
